title: Friday, 21st September 2018
bodyHTML:
11:09 am
BE11:10am

Here we go again, then. Markets Live, FT Alphaville's whatever with the thing.

Soundbuy Morning
Manxish Happy Friday assorted persons
BE11:10am

Again, late start.

Manxish That article on the washed up yacht in NC is really quite fantastic. Kudos to Brendan.
BE11:11am

Because as well as doing this I've just filed .... 959 words to run elsewhere.

tonyb Morning Neil, What's up with Nyrstar?
11:11 am
BE11:11am

BE11:12am

I'm old enough to remember filing the first story of the day at 8pm. Bloody internet.

BE11:13am

So ... there are some obvious things to do ..........

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Just Sell, of course ..........

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 666.40, down 41.6 (-5.88%), High: 693.40, Low: 644.20, Volume: 4.81m
#REF! hello its a Friday. I've got a weekend of furniture assembly to look forward to. Hopefully you all have slightly more rock and roll plans
Bluesky21 UberEats + Deliveroo?
Stateless I really hope uber doesn't ruin deliveroo
#REF! and yes yacht article is interesting, in a "rich people can get away without cleaning up their own mess" kinda way

And I can also recommend Brendan's pretty great post on boats, which is hopefully the first in a series we've provisionally called: "Just because Trump said it doesn't mean it's wrong."

https://ftalphavil...t-have-a-new-boat/

BE11:16am

Request also for Nyrstar, which has a big and ugly overnight profit warning. We'll come to that in time.

Shinshin @BE is there a tickerboard in the office with a wordcount league table ?
undefined
rise2010 From RBS interview on LBC: Ross McEwan: "...when the government is selling down we can actually buy shares back at the same time, which means giving the capital back through that mechanism"

Okay, so here's the Bloomberg story on Deliveruber.

https://www.bloomb...europe-s-deliveroo

Forester Fascinating how Liberium appear to be **** polishing the Uber/Deliveroo tie up with regards to JE. I thought it was all about the rush to be the dominant player........
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Market reaction's understandably jittery, for Just Eat in particular.

FATDAZ @rise2010 so the bank can use the govt own money to reduce their investment that's just mad
BE11:19am

Because, as you'll remember, Just Eat is trying to build out its own moped fleet at the moment. The cost of which gets bumped higher every time management speak .....

BE11:20am

.......... while Deliveroo's launched a Marketplace thing that seems to step directly into Just Eat's own-delivery territory yet involves very little incremental cost at all.

Blank canvas morning all
11:20 am
BE11:21am

Uber + Deliveroo = Just Eat needing to shove a stupid amount of money into defending its position in the core UK market against a company with a seemingly limitless supply of VC money to burn.

Forester ...and now the possibility of sharing your Uber ride with a nice Thai or an Indian on the back seat!
LK Hyman @ Manxish The yacht owner should have bought a boat with a set of big twin diesels instead of sails, then he could have outrun the hurricane.
BE11:22am

Canaccord's comment can be summarised, "ah crap."

Stateless @BE There's nothing 'seemingly' about ubers cash pile
BE11:22am

Investors have flocked to Just Eat and other portal companies, driving their share prices ever higher, attracted by the magic of network effects and winner takes-all advantages. The economics are beguiling: a fast mover gets some customers on board one side of its platform, like diners, it attracts customers on the other side, like restaurants which in turn makes it more attractive for diners. Just Eat, Domino's, Deliveroo, UberEats, Amazon et al, have grown very rapidly but it is too early to call them winners, indeed we believe that the battle has only just begun....

Soundbuy @Forester ...........hmmm...........not to sure how to take that...
11:22 am
BE11:22am

But there are other arguments to make.

BE11:22am

Such as the "less competition means less competition" argument.

BE11:23am

Which Goldman has a go at.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

3 would become 2 - were this combination to occur, the UK
market would move from being arguably (as Deliveroo and UberEats
have almost no marketplace businesses, Just Eat’s core profit
centre) a three-player food delivery platform market to a two player
one. Traditional market theory suggests that this would be positive
for industry profit pools.

CS1 @FAT: isn’t that part and parcel of financialisation
FATDAZ Re the whole food delivery and fulfilment space I don't see who these providers are more cost effective than each take away having its own casual delivery drivers if it's only about economies of scale I doubt there are enough customers in the whole UK to make it viable or profitable
BE11:24am

And the "nothing much changes" argument, again via Goldman.

BE11:24am

UberEats has already been in the UK since 2016 - many of the
more bearish arguments we have heard today in the context of this
news focus on Just Eat potentially having a competitor with far
greater financial capacity than it has. However, we note that Just
Eat has been competing with UberEats in the UK for over two years
already.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Which, okay, sure I guess.

anonymous254 @Fatdaz, was thinking exactly the same, but know nothing of the space so happy to be corrected by those more knowledgeable.
BE11:25am

Then there's the most outlandish argument, which comes somewhat surprisingly from Just Eat permabear JP Morgan Caz.

BE11:25am

We believe Uber shareholders will face difficulties to ask for a meaningful premium. We believe Deliveroo shareholders will not be in a strong position to ask for a significant premium given that Uber might look for alternatives (i.e. Just EAT). Such an event (a merger between Uber and JUST EAT) would create major problems for Deliveroo putting the business model on a stand-alone basis at risk.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Hm ............

BE11:26am

Just Eat's problem -- or advantage, plausibly -- is that it's not gig economy.

FATDAZ @CS1 I suppose once we accepted QE as normality suppose we should be surprised by any thing but the sheer Brassneck of it all gets to me
Stateless @FATDAZ Imo the logic works well. Otherwise the GBK, Nandoes, Wagamamas and Five guys that are literally next to each other all have to operate their own delivery drivers? Going to the same apartment buildings, separately?
BE11:26am

Deliveroo folds into Uber very very easily. Just Eat ....... doesn't.

wayneJ Very interesting article earlier in the week that one of the accountancy firms saying youngsters no longer want to live in London. That surely impacts demand for home delivery services?
FATDAZ @ annon254 yes my comments based on intuition not insight as well so let's see
11:27 am
BE11:27am

It might be cheaper (in the sense that you can value it on an EV-EBITDA basis without running out of digits on your calculator) but it's also a completely different prospect, M&A wise.

BE11:28am

Which leads us down another path ..... what about the CMA?

Forester JE has competition in big cities and in small towns/villages such as where I am, it does not work. Its only real strength is in mid sized places - frankly I would not touch with a bargepole!
jaws Any thing in EQUINTI please ? EQN , thanks.
BE11:29am

You'll remember the CMA took a run at Just Eat-Grubhub last year: https://assets.pub...ional-findings.pdf

FATDAZ @Stateless possibly but my experience working in a millennial office in Shoreditch is that separate drivers turn up for separate deliveries but rationalisation may be phase 2
anonymous254 Anecdotal, but my experience of using the platforms in London with other half, is that you end up going to the same 3 takeaways via the platform, as you know they are good. Which is same from customer perspective as going directly to them. Not sure what the platforms add, but other half likes them, so maybe there is something in it.
11:30 am
BE11:30am

A lot of the analysis focuses on direct-ordering versus last-mile delivery fulfillment and whether they're distinct markets.

Forester I cant believe the CMA are wasting their time - JE cannot price gouge as any attempt would result in businesses cutting them or even lazy millennials getting off their jacksies and picking up their own order!
BE11:31am

The latter's a duopoly. Just Eat's beginning to do the last-mile delivery fulfillment stuff but it's nowhere yet.

BE11:31am

So .... based around that ...... why are we assuming the CMA will give the nod to Deliveruber?

11:32 am
undefined
Binocular @BE, 11.21, wasn't it ever thus?
Forester Deliverubber......now that would potentially be a useful service!
FATDAZ @annon254 so have platforms interposed themselves in such a way that consumers will end up paying more or takeaways won't absorb costs of deployment and will pass them on in the end?
Shinshin Why is this a CMA issue ? Plenty of alternative ways to get service from a takeaway place.
BE11:33am

(@Shinshin: dunno, mate, but the 16 pages of analysis from the CMA that I provided a link to suggests it might be.)

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Smiths follows the old Logica rule where, if you have a business with five bits, two will always be underperforming.

BE11:36am

Caz downgrades in a note not saying much.

BE11:37am

Group revenue and operating profits were slightly below our and consensus expectations. Organic growth for the group increased in H2 2018, taking full year growth up to 2%, compared with zero % in H1 2018. The FX headwind resulted in reported revenue declining by 2%. As expected there was a sharp bounce in organic growth in the Detection division and the pace of organic growth accelerated in most other divisions. The integration of Morpho has progressed smoothly resulting in the cost savings being delivered more swiftly than anticipated. We expect 2019 to be a year of steady progress in the operating performance of the group. With limited upside to our price target we are reducing our recommendation to Neutral from Overweight.

FATDAZ @Flanneur put like that it all sounds about like hitchhikers guide to the galaxy
Stateless @Fatdaz - sometimes they turn up with 1. But I still really believe scale makes so much sense, otherwise each place would have to hire manage maintain their own employees. My evidence is that none of the places deliveroo uses did deliveries before they came along
cheeckychappy @BE - can you explain something to me. The piece in the FT says tomorrow Sky auction is "winner takes all". However what happens if by the third round both 21st Century Fox and Comcast on are on the same price, which is a possibility albeit slim...
Viking1 Apax tried a few years ago to buy the medical
Stateless @cheekychappy I'd like to think they flip a coin :)
11:38 am
BE11:38am

And Goldman grumbles a bit about the outlook.

BE11:38am

In 2019 we forecast 2% underlying growth, and management expect to at least sustain underlying growth. However, commentary surrounding it being 2H weighted could concern investors given that the first half comp is not more challenging (Smiths grew -1% in 1H18 vs. +5% in 2H18, likely due to Medical issues requiring time to resolve). The decline in growth in Interconnect may be a concern to investors given management had sold some of the “slower” growing assets, Smiths attributed this as due to it being a division under transformation.

LK Hyman Smiths is a fine business but there seems little logic or synergy to the various divisions being in the same group. Surprising that a type-Melrose hasn't taken a crack at them before now.
FATDAZ @Statelesd for those that didn't them I can see an instant attraction.
FATDAZ Then I see should say
Bluesky21 Why is Smiths a fine business?

VV75 @Soundbuy I was fishing for a Fevertree update, if there is one.
BE11:49am

We double downgrade Nyrstar to Underperform following 2H18 group profit warning mainly due to sustained low zinc prices. Balance sheet concerns back in focus with EUR350mn senior notes due in 12 months. Another equity issue imminent. Zinc headwinds are likely to sustain beyond 2019 with pressures from new smelters in china and lower galvanising demand

11:49 am
BE11:50am

And Exane.

BE11:50am

FCF was negative EUR51m in H1. Consensus FY18e FCF was a small cEUR12m positive before the material earnings cut that this profit warning implies. Both the bond and equity markets were already nervous given the group’s levered balance sheet with ND/EBITDA of ~5.4x by end FY18e on our revised numbers and combined debt maturities of EUR595m in 2019. A negative FCF would compound those risks, with Port Pirie’s full contribution still at least two years away. In late August, the market debate on how to calculate the group’s all-inclusive debt level got revived: including all pre-pays, net debt at end 1H18 was EUR1.68bn compared to EUR1.2bn reported.

jaws BE anything in SPI or EQN please ?
BE11:50am

Lower earnings and the weak balance sheet drive our valuation to EUR3 per share (34% downside). Headwinds in zinc TCs look set to prevail, and the zinc cycle seems to have passed its peak. 2019 should benefit from zinc hedging and potential TC improvement (but from a low base), Myra Falls volumes, but the drop in bond value has made refinancing very expensive. The path until the benefits of the large Port Pirie investment kick-in looks set to remain a rocky one.

Bluesky21 Equinti is like Capita, but smaller and younger ...
Viking1 Regal petroleum?
11:51 am
BE11:51am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:51am

Comments around a positive FCF for the full-year would need an
H2 cash generation of at least €85mn, thus implying a working capital release of more than €60mn (assuming H2 EBITDA of ~€100mn less capex of €105mn and interest payments of €55mn). Today's profit warning reemphasizes the importance of delivering Port Pirie on time to avoid further cash burn and a consequent rise to an already high financial leverage ratio (ND/Spot EBITDA of ~6x).

Here's Credit Suisse, cutting numbers due to the NHS using triage as stealth privatisation.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Costs rise faster than expected: Despite the August pre-announcement,
Spire’s H1 EPS missed our forecast by 10%. Stagnant revenues were
coupled with labour cost increases as it invested in clinical personnel with a view to raising care quality but also boosted pay for the most low-paid in a tight job market. Drug cost ate into margins, driven by a shift from
orthopaedics to oncology, which we believe creates a headwind to a forecast margin improvement next year. We cut our target price form 215p to 170p, balancing £30-40m pa lower forecast capex with higher operating costs.

Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 155.90, up 0.4 (+0.26%), High: 156.90, Low: 150.60, Volume: 890.39k
BE12:00pm

Revenues to gradually recover but we are 13% below £1.2bn company
guidance 2022E: We keep our forecast of revenue growth accelerating
from -0.5% in FY18E to 2% and 3% in FY19E and FY20E, respectively.
Although, we expect Spire to gain market share, we see more downside than upside risk to the already challenging market backdrop.

tonyb does anyone have a price of the Nyrstar bonds maturing next year?
wayneJ A typical restaurant might have a 1hr turnaround on a table at peak; add ten minutes of delay due to the kitchen being overloaded and it starts impacting profits.
Pharma @Flaneur, is this the new way to find out if it's windy outside?
FATDAZ @excel yes and a rejig of tech sector classification in s&p indices too
12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

EPS downgraded by 19-37% FY18-20E: Higher drugs and labour costs
dent our EBITDA forecasts by £8-10m pa 2018-20E, while EBIT is depressed further £8-10m by higher depreciation stemming from recent years’ investments. Our FY18-20E EPS forecasts are 15-33% below consensus.

BE12:01pm

■ Catalysts and Risks: A takeover of the company at a substantial premium. The shortage of qualified care personnel, notably nurses, is likely to tighten because of high dependency on foreign staff in the UK hospital sector. Raised political sensitivities about waiting lists could prompt a more rapid recovery in NHS revenues than forecast. Financial difficulties of competitors could accelerate Spire’s market share gains of privately funded patients.

Pharma @WayneJ - scope for surge pricing?
Tom Dalgleish @Wayne so some form of lull marketing is needed

wayneJ I was talking to the manager of a restaurant in London about a month ago and he knew his table turnaround times, and the delays for the bill etc right down to the minute. He had worked hard to reduce the delays to increase his turnover - even altering menu options and pricing to ensure his 'production' line in the kitchen could cope
jaws BE thank you very much.
Blank canvas thanks for everything this week. Until Monday ...

Thought midday, but there are still a couple of things to mention.

BE12:04pm

Moss Bros loss.

Moss Bros Group PLC (MOSB:LSE): Last: 40.69, down 5.81 (-12.49%), High: 41.10, Low: 33.00, Volume: 410.88k
12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

The main surprise here being that Moss Bros still exists. We tend to forget about it entirely between profit warnings.

BE12:05pm

Here's Peel Hunt, house broker.

BE12:05pm

Moss has released interim results ahead of schedule, with H1
PBT of £0.2m falling short of our £1.1m forecast. It has been a
tough period for Moss, with Q1 sales hit by poor availability and
then Q2 hit by low footfall as the distractions of football and hot
weather took hold. Trading levels have improved over the first
seven weeks of H2, especially online, although this is still not
enough to catch up to forecasts. We downgrade 2018FY PBT by
£1.8m to £0.5m, with similar downgrades to future years. Moss
has confirmed that dividends will be maintained in line with the
group’s accelerated dividend policy (to pay down excess cash)
and so the shares continue to yield an impressive 8.6%, backed
by strong cash balances.

Airborne Cigar re Moss Bros - do people still hire dress suits?
alewis2005 @wayneJ that's super interesting - I get the impression that most non-chain restaurants don't care about that stuff

BE12:12pm

Course, what you want is a Winterflood analyst's views on cold fusion. So here you go.

jaws BE good point in that woodford link. Thanks
12:12 pm
BE12:12pm

Despite its potentially disruptive implications, scepticism has historically surrounded this branch of science. Industrial Heat was funded to engage credible world-leading institutions to rigorously assess the claims of research groups in the field. According to the manager, over the course of the past 18 months, there have been developments within Industrial Heat's portfolio of technologies that have shown increasing promise. This progress attracted new institutional investors to its most recent funding round, in which Woodford Investment Management also participated, with the proceeds to be used to continue the path to commercialisation. The valuation of Industrial Heat has been adjusted to reflect this progress. The manager noted that while this is positive for Industrial Heat and the fund, it remains early days in the development and commercialisation of these technologies.

BE12:12pm

This is good news for Woodford Patient Capital, with the significant boost to the NAV taking it back above the value at launch. There has obviously been significant progress made by Industrial Heat, and the 357% valuation uplift demonstrates the asymmetric returns that can be achieved in early stage companies, although we note the manager’s comments that it remains early days in the development and commercialisation of its technologies.

In our view, today’s announcement also demonstrates two further points. Firstly, that the trajectory of this type of business is not always linear. The manager followed Industrial Heat for a number of years before the launch of WPCT and it has been part of the portfolio since launch. It has not been a smooth progression, with the failure of one of the company’s initial technologies and involvement in litigation leading to it being written down. However, it broadened its platform of technologies and it has clearly received enough external validation of progress that it has been able to attract funding from additional institutional investors at a significantly higher valuation.

Our second point is that there can be a lag between positive progress in unquoted portfolio companies and revaluations, which are performed by a third party. It appears that funding rounds or IPOs, which provide a solid basis for the valuation, are the most likely trigger of upwards revaluation, rather than a perhaps more subjective assessment of the value based on progress alone. In our view it is therefore possible that a number of the companies in the portfolio may hold latent value given their progress in the time since their last valuation. This also means that, as has been the case today, returns can be lumpy. So far this morning the fund’s share price has increased by 7.6% but we continue to believe that the current c.12% discount to the pro forma NAV of c.99.6p could prove to be an attractive entry point, particularly if the fund gathers momentum in the months ahead if its underlying holdings continue to report positive developments.
